ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was just a virtual seminar.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to analyze and think deeper about the meaning of bad art and its place in society, as well as how to improve my writing of academic papers.
Writing, close reading, usage of evidence

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was super engaging and fun. The only weakness I would say was that there were some readings we definitely did not get adequate time to discuss, but I feel like that always happens in English classes.

One of the strengths of this course was that it was very engaging because it was primarily discussion based. You also get a lot of feedback about your writing, which is really helpful. One suggestion I do have is that I wish we had done more writing workshops during class.

Strengths - reading material, feedback, subject matter, teacher
Weaknesses - not a lot of time to focus on really great reading material because writing workshopping pulls some focus. a necessary evil as this is an intro writing class

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We did break out rooms a lot which I liked. It was nice to get to know my classmates despite the virtual format.
Everyone kept their camera on, and if possible kept their mic on, which was really helpful in maintaining the flow of the class.
Successes - giving breaks, no pressure to keep camera on

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes absolutely! This class was honestly one of my favorites I've ever taken. If you are interested in pop culture and love trashy stuff, definitely take this class.

Yes! Your writing really improves a lot because Kate gives very detailed feedback and we also workshop each other's essays. You also get to write about what you want most of the time, and the essays that we read are really interesting. The class also incorporates some mixed-media, so we got to look at  cool art pieces and watch fun movies. I would say this class is a must for anyone looking to improve their writing, or just looking for a fun English class to take!
Absolutely! Kate is wonderful, the material is so good and she responds really well to student needs.

extras.title:
ENGL 114 25
        How to Love Bad Art
